key_mistakes.reason: Playing c6 in the opening allows White to gain a space advantage and doesn't challenge the center.
Developing the knight to c3 blocks the c-pawn and doesn't challenge the center immediately.
The bishop move to c4 lacks purpose and allows Black to develop comfortably.
Queen move to d3 doesn't address the threat of Bg4 pinning the knight.
Retreating the bishop to c7 is passive and loses control over important squares.
The queen move to d6 allows White to attack with initiative.
Moving the knight to f5 doesn't address the threats and allows Black to create a decisive attack.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center with your pawns and pieces.
Develop your pieces to active squares and avoid unnecessary retreats.
Ensure your king's safety by addressing threats promptly.
In the Caro-Kann Defense, consider challenging the center early with e5.
